title: 113_s2952
content:
The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the "Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking" in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House of Representatives, with specific expertise in academic research, data management, and program administration. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Three members are appointed by the Minority Leader of the House, and three by the Majority Leader of the Senate, with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking consists of 15 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House of Representatives. Three members are appointed by the Minority Leader of the Senate, with expertise in academic research, data management, program administration, database management, confidentiality, and privacy matters. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson. The President selects the chairperson of the Commission, and the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve without pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission is responsible for specific duties. The Commission is tasked with conducting a comprehensive study of data inventory, infrastructure, and protocols related to Federal policymaking. Recommendations will be made on integrating data for program evaluation and research, modifying infrastructure to meet objectives, and incorporating outcomes measurement. The Commission will study how to incorporate outcomes measurement, randomized controlled trials, and impact analysis into program design. They will also consider creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data, evaluating relevant administrative datasets, survey data linkages, and legal barriers. The Commission will study linkages across administrative data series, legal and administrative barriers to data sharing, data-sharing infrastructure for research, self-funding a clearinghouse, access limitations, privacy protection, using data for program improvement, and incentives for interagency information sharing. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions within 15 months of the majority of members being appointed. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected in any form. The term "administrative data" in this section refers to information generated or collected by an agency in carrying out a Federal program, including various measures and indicators as defined in title 31, United States Code. SEC. 5. OPERATION AND POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will receive administrative assistance from various government agencies and must convene a meeting within 30 days of a majority of members being appointed. The Commission must meet within 30 days of a majority of members being appointed and as determined by the chairperson. Rules of procedure will be established with a quorum requirement. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. It can also contract with government and private agencies for necessary purposes. The Commission may contract with and compensate government and private agencies for necessary purposes. It can use the United States mails, accept gifts, and dispose of donations. The Director of the Census can contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for administration. Principal statistical agencies can provide funds, not exceeding $2,000,000, for the Commission's operations. The principal statistical agencies will provide funds up to $2,000,000 to the Director for the Commission's operations. The term "principal statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget. SEC. 6. PERSONNEL.

The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson and co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services. 

SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
